The Dunkel report then affects some elements that could really put Quebec in a tight spot, and I will give you examples. It provides sanctions for equity investment such as the Societe generale de financement, the Caisse de depot et de placement, the Societe de developpement industriel, Soquip, and so on, have. That means that the action taken by our provincial government can be subject to sanctions. I know that the federal government talks about theoretical sanctions. I remember that the last time we heard about "theoretical sanctions" was during the free trade negotiations. Unfortunately these theoretical sanctions became real sanctions-talk to the people at Norsk Hydro or to the people in British Columbia about softwood lumber.
The loan guarantee programs in Quebec, which are another form of intervention often used in our province, can also be subject to sanctions. Sanctions might also be taken against tax incentives and tax credits in Quebec, according to the Dunkel report. I am sure that the minister of consumer affairs is aware that this includes the stock savings plan as well as flowthrough shares, the occupational training tax credit and even the tax credit used to launch the solidarity fund.
I speak of these programs as activities that can be denounced and subject to sanctions in the Dunkel report because they are called specific subsidies. When they are specific, they can be denounced by any other country that signed the agreement. Unfortunately this could be disastrous for Quebec, not only because Quebec is different in that we have a variety of programs to support our agricultural industry, and also for consumers because if all these sanctions are applied, with free trade, foreign companies and the whole foreign agriculture industry will surely find the field quite open for unfair but legal competition.
Mr. Speaker, my colleague's motion is extremely important and I think it is quite clear, unlike the government's negotiations at GATT. We are very clear in our motion, which reads as follows: "That this House calls on the government to support unequivocally any final GATT accord that-" and this is very simple, since it does at least two things- "provides for the maintenance of viable and effective management programs as an essential element of Canadian agricultural policy". Second, Mr. Speaker, we ask the government to support unequivocally any final GATT accord that: "ensures the ability of Canada, through a clarified article XI, to control effectively imports of milk, eggs, hatching eggs, chicken and turkey, and products containing a majority of supply managed products".
Mr. Speaker, I agree that Quebec's farm sector is not the only one affected by these problems. They affect Canada as a whole, including city dwellers as customers, and people in rural areas as producers. As a consumer advocate, I have tried in recent weeks to find out whether our production system makes food and food products more expensive than they would be in the United States. I have often heard people say this, but today, a Nova Scotia poultry producer told me that in 1982, they got $1.16 for every chicken; 10 years later, in 1992, they are still getting $1.16 for every chicken.
I do not think we are paying too much for our food, but I wonder whether food is cheaper in the United States. Of course it is cheaper. However, I left the United States because I did not want to belong to a society where the individual does not count, and where the traditional farm does not count, where instead people are intent on vertical integration, big business, so-called agribusiness. Mr. Speaker, after giving up the United States to come to Canada and become a Canadian citizen, I would hate to become, oh, irony of ironies, an American living in Canada, after all those 23 years. This is just too much
I have a stake in this debate because I experienced what is happening to the United States, and I experienced what is happening to Canada, and frankly, there is no point in living like Americans and having the kind of businesses Americans have. We have something better here. Perhaps members on the other side of the House do not accept this because it isn't enough. Mr. Speaker, I can tell you that we have a standard of living, social security, medicare and all kinds of programs that make our country different from the United States. I think that one of the reasons why the current GATT talks have caused so much dissatisfaction and even outrage across Canada is that Canadians realize they are about to lose what they had gained.
February 12, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I would like to say in conclusion that I hope this government will not be "all talk and no action".

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, until I heard the minister speak earlier this afternoon I retained some small degree of hope that perhaps the pessimists were wrong and Canada really was going to maintain its supply management system. The free trade agreement has been mentioned. When we were discussing it some three years ago we were reassured, guaranteed by the government, that the marketing board system would be maintained under the free trade agreement. It lasted for just over two years. Now we know, from what the minister said today, that he too has abandoned any hope of maintaining our system of orderly marketing.
What of the minister's choice of language? He has confidence in the system. He could only have been referring to supply management. He is willing to defend it. Supply management is not something that needs defending. Perhaps it should be sold but certainly not defended as though it were something that was lacking in some ways, as though it were something wrong. It is the best system of marketing in the whole world. Canada has been a world leader in developing its system of supply management. Supply management means exactly what the words say.
The minister said that we may have to adjust some plans that interfere with world markets, but supply management does not. Supply management could, but it does not when it is working properly. It works properly in Canada and the minister knows it. In saying he is willing to defend it, he is saying that he does not really believe in it strongly enough to go out there and sell it, to tell the rest of the world that Canada, the United States notwithstanding, is determined to maintain its system of supply management and orderly marketing.
Supply management means exactly what the words say: we manage the amount of supply. We make sure there are just enough of the various commodities under supply management to ensure that the home market is supplied. As I said, we could adjust it upward to supply an export market if we wanted to, if there were a demand, if the world needed it somewhere, if we had an agreement with some country. We could do that. It is that flexible and can react very quickly.
With our system of supply management we are able to maintain the quality. The quality of Canadian food is not surpassed anywhere in the world. We are able to reduce the cost of supplying this food. One of the speakers said earlier that the cost of food to Canadians is the second lowest in the world. That is in large measure due to our supply management system.
We do not have surpluses that we have to dump somewhere. Each commodity looks after its own production so that the amount required for fresh consumption, whether it be eggs, milk, broilers or turkeys, is just enough to supply the fresh market plus enough of a margin, which is processed by the appropriate marketing board, so that there is an ample supply of top quality food available for Canadians. We do not export any of those goods to any degree unless there is a market that has to be filled. We can react very quickly to any shortfall anywhere else. We can increase the production of any of those goods.
The price the producers receive is not outrageous. I was an egg producer during the 1950s, about 40 years ago. The cost of producing those eggs has increased fifteenfold since I was an egg producer. The cost of all the feed, the cost of everything, apart from the labour put in by the proprietor, has increased fifteenfold. The number of birds that a person looks after has increased fifteenfold. The price of the product to the consumer has increased 15 per cent. That is the case with eggs and it is similar for all the other commodities which are supply managed.
It is not possible to do it with everything. It is very difficult to do with it tree fruit because it perhaps could take five years for a tree to come into production. It is very difficult to do it with grain because the amount of production is so unpredictable, and so is the world demand. We just do not know.
We should not be tinkering with our system of supply management. We should do everything we can to maintain it. The minister did not talk too much about the other agricultural products. Of course the one on the table is grain and oilseeds, but supply management does not work there.
Even there it is not a case of support. He talked about supporting, but we are not supporting grain farmers. If we were going to support grain farmers, the best thing we could do for them would be to let them go broke and get off the farm.
Most of them are certainly not doing any more than barely making a living. We are not giving them prices that will enable them to make a good living. We are not giving them prices that will enable them to buy equipment right now. They do not even buy enough fertilizer.
February 12, 1992

They are not able to farm the way they know they could if conditions were right. Those are not support prices. We are not supporting the farmers. We are simply paying the farmers to produce wheat because we need to export it.
Why do we need to export it? We are paying some $27 billion a year in interest charges to foreigners for money they have lent us. We have to give them something. Loonies will not do, so we give them wheat. We give them oilseeds. They are the second largest source of export for Canada.
We are not looking after the farmers. We are not doing it because we like the farmers. We are doing it because we need those exports.
Our system does not need defending. We should be selling it. There are producers of everything all over the world who would like to get into our system of managing the supply for their own needs, of orderly marketing so producers can make a respectable living.
Even then they do not have control of the price. They are accused of holding up the prices, of holding people to ransom. In most of the marketing boards that have any authority to set prices there are people involved in the mechanism of setting prices who have nothing to do with production.
They are there to provide consumer input on prices. I am not sure about the other provinces but I know that, for example, in B.C. the chairman of the milk board for the longest time was a chartered accountant who knew nothing at all about producing milk. He certainly knew how to calculate.
The price of milk the producer received was calculated very closely so that the producer got the cost of production and enough margin to cover the rest of his expenses.
That is the way it is with the other boards. There are people involved in the price setting mechanism who know the costs. They get all the information. They know if there is any need for the price to change one way or the other, up or down. They set the prices very carefully. The farmers still have to do all the gambling on what will happen with respect to weather, diseases and so on.
They are totally at the mercy of diseases from time to time that can wreck people individually, and yet not the industry. Production is country-wide, from Newfoundland to Prince Edward Island to British Columbia.
Supply
Every province has some degree of supply management. Certainly the farmers in the province from which I come, British Columbia, depend to a great extent on supply management to make it possible for them to make a living, to make it possible for them to produce exactly the amount of milk, eggs, broiler hatching eggs, broilers or turkeys required by the market in that province.
We have never heard of any embarrassing surpluses. We have never heard of any shortages and we have never heard of anybody paying more than a fair price.
I am not saying that it cannot be bought cheaper somewhere else, but farmers are getting the cost of production and enough of a margin for it to be reasonable. That is fair to them and it is fair to the consumer.
We should not be defending our system of orderly marketing, our system of marketing boards. We should be out there making it possible for the farmers in other countries to learn from our experience and adopt similar systems so that they will be treated fairly and consumers in their countries will be treated fairly.

I have watched what is happening. I encourage them, but the inference I took from what the minister said today was that if they were able to accomplish it, by the time they got it working the government would have pulled the rug out from under their feet and would have sold out to the U.S.A.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take part in this debate today. One thing this debate is doing, and especially the discussions of the past few weeks, is to make us realize that the Canadian agrifood industry is facing major changes not only in Canada but all over the world.
To use a common expression, the agrifood industry is once again at the crossroads. More than ever, it is critical to follow the development of consumer markets. Under pressure from all sides, technologies are developing incredibly fast. Eating habits are also changing, becoming
more varied. Companies develop new business strategies with a view to positioning themselves in the context of market globalization. That is to say that the stakes are high and extend far beyond our provincial borders, even our national borders. Of course, our agrifood industry is affected by all this. It has no choice but to adjust to these changes, and I think most of the people in this industry are willing to take up this challenge.
In fact farmers, processors and food retailers to name but a few are ready to do whatever it takes. Since their production is their livelihood, they are sensitive to market fluctuations. They know that if they make the right decisions, they stand to gain a great deal.
There are driving forces within this industry striving to innovate and to be competitive. As I mentioned earlier, in spite of the doom and gloom scenario predicted in 1998 of what might result from the free trade deal with the United States, here we are with major increases in our exports, i.e. between 25 and 30 per cent, for the first two years. In the dairy and poultry industries as well our exports have increased, which means that things are never as bad as we are led to believe.
Mr. Speaker, one thing is sure and that is that our agrifood industry has constantly improved. Many of the agricultural products we export compare favourably with any other in the world. It would be even more so if international trade rules applied equally to every country. That is why we are working so hard to make things move at GATT. When I say we, I mean members of the cabinet, but also our negotiators, people who support us, and I should add people in the provinces, in the food industry, in agriculture, and even, to some extent, a large number of members of this House who, despite the fact that speeches are sometimes partisan, seem nevertheless to support the Canadian position, which has the advantage of being supported by everybody.
Moreover, our message is clear. It is clear to us, it is clear to other members of GATT and it is mainly clear to the stakeholders in the Canadian agrifood industry. Need we repeat a thousand times, Mr. Speaker, that our position reflects in every detail what came out of the
February 12, 1992

Supply
consultations we held with the industry? It is not the position of the Canadian government we are defending at GATT, but the position of the Canadian agrifood industry. It is our producers who came up with this historic compromise, whether it be in the grain industry, in the area of minimum access to market, in the supply management sectors for milk and poultry. I repeat, this is not just the position of the Canadian government, of cabinet ministers, of members of this House; this is the position of farmers. This is the position of provincial governments. Naturally this is the position our government endorsed, and the position I am proud to defend.
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian system of supply management was set up according to GATT rules. This system today, just like yesterday, is a success. Many countries came here to look at it as a possible model for them. This a marketing model of which Canadians are justly proud. With this system our producers receive a fair reward for their labour. For their part, processors and consumers can expect a regular and constant supply of quality products at reasonable prices.
Clearly, just like in any other industries not under supply management, it is necessary to make periodic adjustments to follow changes in the marketplace. I believe people in the industry are willing to adapt, to co-operate with us in government, to make the system of supply management more responsive to the marketplace. This is what we did, Mr. Speaker, when we reviewed agricultural programs.
As I just said, the supply management system is based on GATT rules. One of the contentious issues at the talks in Geneva concerns article XI, which provides for the control of imports for supply management.
Mr. Speaker, we have noticed in recent years-and it must be mentioned-that this article XI on which we relied heavily, particularly for our supply management system, had a deficiency which may not have been foreseen 40 years ago, when the GATT was signed. However, if you read the report of the GATT panel on yogurt and ice cream, you have no choice but to acknowledge that article XI, in its present form, does not adequately protect products marketed under supply management systems, particularly processed products. And since we find ourselves with an agricultural economy in which new processed and over-processed products now represent a greater share of the market, those products must be protected through a supply management system; otherwise it will become increasingly difficult to maintain the system.
Mr. Speaker, that is why, in response to a request from producers, we drafted a new article XI that accurately reflects their needs and that should enable us to protect our Canadian system.
It is somewhat insulting-that is how I feel, Mr. Speaker-that other countries want us to give up that article or that protection so that they can change their own system, which is based on exceptions, whereas ours is based on written rules that seemed clear at the time and that enabled us to have a system. It is not right to penalize Canadian farmers because other countries want to go back to rules that are more in line with those of international trade.
I do hope that it will be possible to make our partners, the other members of the international community, understand Canada's position. We are not asking for favours. We are a trading country that always abided by the rules of international trade. So have the provinces, the producers and the processors. I believe that this is the way to behave.
The Canadian government refuses to be forced, after 20 years, to change a system that works. Canada does not unload food surpluses on the other members of the international community. Canada disciplined itself; it reduced its own domestic supplies and limited its activities to its own market. In exchange, it asked for control at the border. What Canada asks again today is the right to be able to maintain control over access to its market, based on Canadians' capacity. Mr. Speaker, Canada is asking for justice.
I ask all my colleagues in this House to support Canada's position, as you have done, and I thank most of the members who rose to indicate their support. The government is not alone in this. We must transcend the party lines, we must go beyond mere partisanship, in order to support Canadian producers. For once, we have the ability to transcend the political discussions, Mr. Speaker, and to work together-
The Prime Minister announced today that he will meet farm leaders early next week. Together we will develop our strategy. Together we have defined Canada's position, and our government is open to all suggestions regarding its strategy. We will probably have to go back to Europe to meet some people who might be able to help.
Mr. Speaker, as long as the agreement is not signed by all 108 member countries, we will fight to make sure that what we want in order to preserve our marketing agencies will find its way into the final report Mr. Dunkel will be presenting. That is the goal for which we have

been working so hard and so relentlessly for almost two years.
True, we have not succeeded yet. We are honest enough to admit it. We have not succeeded yet. The fight is fierce, but that is exactly why, Mr. Speaker, we must work side by side. We do not have any other choice, but only in a great country like Canada is such historical consensus possible. I am sure we will be successful and that will make Canadians, each and every one of us, very proud.

I am wondering what specifically the Prime Minister is doing in Washington to get this support.
The minister is also responsible for consumer affairs. The minister knows that his department, or a department within the Ministry of Agriculture, gave the Consumers Association money to do a study on supply management. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am veiy happy to have this opportunity to deal with agriculture, and particularly the present GATT negotiations. Since I have been elected to this House to represent the constituency of Beauce, in Quebec, I have worked hard and taken a keen interest in agriculture, as the representative of a semi-rural semi-urban county which qualifies as the kingdom of small and medium sized businesses. But beside these farm manufacturing firms, we have at least 3,000 producers of pork, eggs, poultry, particularly dairy products, and so on.
As the years went by, I have learned here in Parliament and in the various committees, that our government has worked very hard to support the Canadian and Quebec agriculture. Today, we hear prophets of doom say that in the present GATT negotiations, which have lasted more than a year, this government has sold us down the river. I wonder where that information comes from, because the Government of Canada has always fiercely supported our farmers, whatever the type of farming they do and in whatever region of Canada they live.
Last Friday, Mr. Speaker, the federal and provincial ministers of agriculture have stated again their complete and unshakeable support of our government position which is to bring to a successful conclusion these GATT negotiations. And, when I speak about the provincial and federal ministers of agriculture, I include all the heads of the various producers' unions across the country.
Canada's position within the GATT negotiations, developed in co-operation with farmers' associations and
Supply
the provinces, essentially strives for a clearer definition and a strengthening of article XI, a substantial reduction of trade distorting grants and an easier access to international markets.
I must add that the Canadian position has never changed on that matter. In representing the Beauce region fanners, I have often stressed the importance of protecting the supply management system essential to milk, egg and poultry producers. I have stressed, for my colleagues and for the government, and my comments were well received and accepted, the fact that we recognize the absolute necessity of working closely with the agrifood industry if Canada's well-balanced position is to progress. Mr. Speaker, to understand the uncertainty in the minds of the dairy and poultry producers today in Canada I have to reflect back to the minister's statement of September 18, page 2312 of Hansard, when he said: "The policy of this government is that article XI should be further clarified and strengthened. That position has not changed and will not change until the government says it will change".
It left the door open. Then, on page 6369 of Hansard, a plan is referred to by the Prime Minister. He said that the Tories are now working on a plan to offer better protection than the present formula.
In looking at these statements it is not much wonder that the dairy and poultry farmers of Canada are fearful of what lies ahead. They are fearful that their system, which is the best in the world and has not contributed to world surpluses, will be traded away in secret, behind closed doors.
Of course, we heard the Minister for International Trade a year ago. A year ago last October he chastised the Minister of Agriculture in this House for giving the farmers such huge subsidies: $8.8 billion worth of subsidies.

February 12, 1992
Supply
Of that, $2.2 billion went to dairy farmers. That was a concocted figure. The actual figure was $267 billion to the industrial milk producers of Canada. The fluid milk producers got nothing. The difference was the difference in price between what Canada's dairy farmers received and what the U.S. farmers received. They call that a "subsidy".
Look at the difference between the industry in Canada, a healthy, vibrant industry that supplies the Canadian consumer with ample quantities of excellent products at reasonable prices, and the system of utter chaos in the United States, where literally thousands upon thousands of dairy farmers are being forced out of business.
I was very upset when I saw a newspaper headline in today's The Ottawa Citizen quoting a statement by David Simpson, executive director of the Canadian Consumers' Association and the Consumer's Group, that he: "foresees lower prices under proposed GATT rules".
Another headline in The Montreal Gazette on February 11 said: "Dairy industry mooches off Canadians who are stuck buying expensive milk". They claim in those articles that the average dairy farmer in Canada, of whom there are 38,000 in fact, is getting $15,000 in subsidies each.
That is absolutely wrong. It is absolutely wrong. Not once have I heard the Minister of Agriculture or the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs get up and correct the record. I have to ask the minister why he is not taking the lead to correct these erroneous statements. Why does he not defend his producers at home here in Canada? Is he using the same laid back tactics in defence of our marketing board systems at GATT?
I wish to point out to the minister that we did a study in my office last summer. We called it "Compare the Share" and it showed where the largest increases in price to the consumer took place.
During the last 10 years 2 per cent milk increased 19 cents a litre at the farm gate but 73 cents to the
consumer, an increase of 97 per cent; cheese showed a very moderate increase to the producer and the manufacturer, but at the retail level an increase of 86 per cent. There was a 29 per cent increase to the chicken producer and 87 per cent to the consumer. This is almost double the rate of inflation and this government and the Bank of Canada jack up interest rates to control inflation, letting this go by. I am going to give the minister a copy of that study and, hopefully, he will come to the defence of our Canadian farmers here at home, set the record straight and remind Canadian consumers and the Canadian people that they have the second lowest food costs of any nation in the world. Mr. Speaker, I am also pleased to have the opportunity tonight to be able to speak to the motion and the amendments on the table and to add my voice and that of Atlantic Canada to the debate on agriculture and the GATT, particularly article XI and the role of supply management.
It is an unfortunate but growing trend in Canada that when we have an industry or an institution that is successful, which has become part of the Canadian way of life and which has become an integral part of the economic or social fabric of the nation, then that is the industry or institution we have to meddle with, we have to reorganize, privatize or dismantle it. We seem to have an obsession to either tamper with or not defend or defend half-heartedly those areas which are most successful. We seem to be ashamed of our success. This is the new world order.
Such is the situation we find ourselves in today with our agricultural sector. Our dairy, egg and poultry industries all operate successfully with little or no government support. These are supply managed industries. Now these particular industries find themselves in jeopardy. The GATT negotiations threaten to replace the supply management system.
This change, if it comes to pass, will force our supply management producers to sacrifice a lifetime of effort and investment in order to satisfy the demands of others, particularly the Americans, so they can gain access to our markets.
While the official Canadian negotiating position calls for clarification and enhancement of article XI, there is a growing concern and suspicion in the country that the government's position may be softening. Rumours persist that Canada may agree to abandon supply management boards. This was stated by Lome MacNeill, chairman of the P.E.I. egg marketing board, when he said: "I am veiy scared that Ottawa will not be there for farmers. Tariffs would eliminate small producers very fast". This is typical of sentiments expressed by farm leaders and management board people across the country. I do think that over the past weeks the producers have been able to stiffen the backbone of the government in this regard.

February 12, 1992
Supply
There is an underlying fear that the government is already preparing tariffication schedules and thus weakening our negotiating hand before we actually have to decide whether to sign the GATT.
Producers believed the government was fighting hard on their behalf until the minister said in St. John's, Newfoundland, and I quote from yesterday's edition of the farm newspaper Farm and Country: "At the dairy farmers of Canada meeting in St. John's, Newfoundland, when the minister was pressed to say whether or not article XI would be protected, he is quoted as saying I cannot guarantee that article XI will prevail". This came as a shock to the dairy farmers of Canada. They believed everything was fine. They thought that as of last December. If the Dunkel report had not come out what would have happened at that time was that the government would have signed the agreement without even the supply managed producers knowing that it was going to sign away their particular commodities on the altar of free trade.
This prompted Peter Gould, who is an Ontario Milk Board economist, to say that he just cannot see the logic in Canada playing the tariffication card before the GATT poker game even starts. He goes on to say that people are saying Canada is the Boy Scout in international trade. This is very unfair to Boy Scouts. It tarnishes their image. He goes on to say that Canadians are dupes. Gould says: "We give things away before we have to". Gould and others say that the government is doing a sales job on tariffication to make it palatable to Canadians. He says: "You have the Easter Bunny, you have Santa Claus and you have tariffication. You might as well throw in the Tooth Fairy along with them".
It is essential that intervention be made at the highest level in order to lay these fears to rest. It is imperative that the Prime Minister meet with his counterparts in the U.S. and the European Community again. He must defend our supply management system when the very survival of our dairy, poultry and egg industries is at stake.
I do not think our farmers should expect or have to settle for anything less than our national leaders going to the wall to defend their interests and by extension the national interest of all Canadians.
I wish the Prime Minister and our negotiators success and support in these final negotiations.
While this is a national problem I would like to direct most of my remaining remarks to the situation in Atlantic Canada and what the impact on that region will be if our system of supply management is scrapped in favour of tariffication.
Producers are asking for clarification of article XI, not tariffication.
In Atlantic Canada the national problems are compounded by our distance from supplies and from markets. Loss of our supply management system would be a devastating blow to those industries and to the economy of Atlantic Canada.
In the words of the Milk Marketing Board chairman, Gordon MacBeath, "It would mean the end of the dairy industry in this country. We would see massive imports of dairy products from the U.S. into central Canada, and under pressure to keep their markets in central Canada, these central Canadian dairies would start moving into the eastern markets. It would be the end of the small dairy holdings."
Farm organizations throughout Atlantic Canada, the four premiers, the four agriculture ministers, and the four members of Parliament are all on record supporting in strongest possible terms the concept of supply management. They insist that Canada must not agree to the tariffication proposed. It is their considered opinion that it would be tragic if the future of supply management is not secured in these final negotiations.
Just to conclude, I would like to say that the move to tariffication would, in essence, deliberately create in our country a region which would be virtually incapable of producing basic foods. Contrary to the argument that supply management fosters inefficiency and higher prices, we will find that food prices in Atlantic Canada will actually increase.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my riding is Perth-Wellington-Waterloo which comprises all that great county of Perth and parts of the two great counties beside it, Wellington and Waterloo.
Indeed, it is a great county in the supply management area. In my riding I have over 1,000 supply managed milk producers and I would think between 75 and 100 supply managed poultry producers. Of course, all the milk and poultry producers are under the supply management scheme.
We are debating a very serious matter here today. It is indeed what I told the producers in my riding would happen at the end of all of the debate we have had for five years on the matter of supply management and article XI.
We are at the crisis time. This is the time when the real answers would be coming out. It was not particularly the free trade issue at the time. As the last member said, it was a matter of GATT and here we are. We are at the final end.
You would have noticed if you were in the House a little while ago or watching. I asked a question of a senior member of the opposition which was in government a long time ago and I hope never will be back there again. I asked the member: Do we need a GATT agreement?
He would not answer. He ducked the question. He simply would not answer the question. That is not a privilege that we have. We in government have to look at the greater good. Indeed we must have a GATT agreement; we must be part of it.
We have serious other problems in agriculture that demand that agreement as well. This does not take away my support for our position which was hammered out between the Government of Canada and the supply managed producers that we should stick with their position and our position right to the end.

February 12, 1992
Supply
Indeed, this might be a degree of a hazard, because if we were losing on the matter-and I believe that we are going to win on this matter at least to a degree-and we cannot debate the other factors that might come into the agreement, we could very well lose some advantages there that we could have gained had we been part of the negotiations.
I feel today and felt this particularly earlier in the debate that we have people who know something about the farming community. Certainly members of the Standing Committee on Agriculture have been speaking, but we heard about all farmers, all family farms.
I want to say that we are abusing a large number of other family farms, in fact, the majority of family farms that are not supply managed. We must keep in mind here, as a group, that the farmers are divided between supply managed farmers and those who are not. Those who are not are the majority.
That does not say, however, anything against the importance of this particular segment of the poultry and dairy operations and of the importance of supply management. Supply management has given us stability in the farming regions, particularly in my region, that was not seen 25 and 30 years ago in my capacity as a veterinarian serving these farmers.
I saw the lack of stability. I saw the people who geared up, bought the tanks and equipment, bought the cows, fixed their bams, to sell to a market in Toronto. I saw them lose that market just on a whim. I saw them fighting for price on a product that was perishable, that would not stay fresh for very long.
Now under supply management they have stability. That stability has generated a stability in rural life as well. As we go along the country roads-my farmers remind me of this regularly-in Ontario and indeed, I am sure anywhere where we have supply managed products, you see very fine, properly maintained buildings. Our dairy and poultry farmers are able to put together a stable structure and keep it up.
They are able to practice sustainable agriculture because they have a decent return on their production. Supply management has allowed them a stable rural structure.
Supply management has kept the family farm stronger than it would be otherwise. The words family farm are overused, but terribly important. The family farm as we know it is a matter of a family owning and supplying all the labour for that farm. But in the case of the family farm under supply management there are about 2.5 people working on that farm. I assume they must be supporting something like 2.5 families on average.
I would suggest that is probably the future of supply management with or without the agreement. Farms are going to get bigger and the family farm will be a place where several farm families work and have a decent life with time off.
Supply management has given us a safe and secure supply of milk and poultiy products. There is little direct subsidy. We heard a figure of $267 million going directly to manufactured milk producers. What they get out of the market is based on a border that is relatively closed, not totally closed, to the import of our product and on a cost of production formula. There may be some degree of subsidy going into the products in that particular respect.
I want the non-farm people to know this because it is important. The amount of money our supply managed farmers get in any form is equal to or less than that which American farmers get through their system. They supposedly have no subsidy yet there are many areas in which they do get it. Supply management provides a product, stability and a secure and safe supply without excess subsidy which other countries would supply.
When I looked at the motion this morning, I found I was going to have difficulty in supporting it. I have two or three areas I might mention before I sit down.
I noticed that the term unequivocally was used. It did not say: Do not support an agreement that does not include this. It says: Support this if it is there. It was not strong enough that we really want to push right to the very end to support our position on supply management.
February 12, 1992

I noticed as well that in the original motion somehow the drafters of the motion in the NDP talked about milk, eggs, hatching eggs, chicken and turkey but left out other products with potential supply management possibilities. I would mention in particular the apple industry. I would think the maple syrup industry would be a logical one in Quebec.
I felt the motion lacked in that particular regard as well. The area I was particularly concerned about in this motion was the fact of the Crow benefit. Somehow the NDP, and indeed we have heard it endorsed by a speaker from the Liberal Party, would prejudge how the Crow benefit should be paid. Do not consult. Do not go to the farmers as a whole. TMk only to their supporters and prejudge how it would be paid. I maintain that we must talk to the farmers and we must come up with a consensus about the best way to handle this benefit. We must make sure they still get the same amount of benefit or an adjusted amount as it increases.
I want to say that I am totally behind this motion as amended. I was a little concerned about the subamendment from the Official Opposition that directed how the Prime Minister would get involved. We know he is involved. We know of his concern for agriculture. We know he will be there on the front lines but they seem to be pinning it down on a particular type of meeting and I was a little concerned there.
I am willing to support this motion. We in the government know how important supply management is to the agricultural industry in Canada. We will carry forward our joint position right to the end in these trade negotiations to get a successful ending.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to be able to participate in this debate.
Having looked at the motion, I see five facets to it. I am going to limit my remarks in the time available to two of them. One is the matter of the Crow benefit. The other is the export subsidies.
In regard to the Crow benefit, members will recall that this historic benefit, dating from 1897, called for the transportation of prairie grain to export at a rate of half a cent a ton mile. "Half a cent a ton mile forever" was the expression that was used in the prairie schoolhouses for many years. Members will know also that that ended back in 1983 with the passage of the Western Grain Transportation Act, which enshrined the then value of the Crow benefit to prairie producers at what now amounts to some $720 million. That $720 million covers about two-thirds of the cost of shipping the prairie grain to export. The other third is borne by the prairie producer.
There are nice arguments ongoing as to whether this Crow benefit should continue to be paid to the railways as specified under the Western Grain Transportation Act or whether there should be a change in the method of payment so that the moneys would go to the actual producer.
That is a bit of a side issue here in the context of the discussion of the Dunkel proposals and any possible GATT accord. -
Over the prairies and other parts of Canada at the present time there have been a series of transportation discussion meetings. These were commissioned as a result of the unanimous agreement of the agriculture ministers of the country back at their meeting in Kana-naskis in July of last year. The 10 provincial ministers and the federal minister agreed that a number of agriculture-related transportation issues would be put out to the farm community for discussion. Among them was the matter of payment of the Crow benefit.
The fact is that the method of payment of the Crow benefit is not really part and parcel of a GATT proposal. It is true that if the Dunkel text was accepted and if a final accord is reached along those lines there could be a reduction in the amount of the Crow benefit. This would be a phased-in reduction over a period of six years. The Crow benefit could however still remain and the method of payment could remain as is.
I think it is a little bit of a side issue to talk in terms of retaining the Crow benefit in its present form in the wording of this particular motion. The fact is that nothing in the proposed GATT wording calls for a change in the method of payment at all.
February 12, 1992

I do want to also address the matter of the export subsidies. I come from a grain-producing area in southwestern and south central Saskatchewan. I would guess my constituency grows the largest amount of wheat for export in the country, certainly the highest quality wheat.
I can say unequivocally that the sale of grain for export is the engine that drives my area and, I believe, drives the Saskatchewan economy as a whole. That is a fact that has been recognized, not just by the government federally, but by successive provincial governments within Saskatchewan. The fact is that agriculture is the number one item and the number one priority. It has been treated as such by this government.
We have faced over the past number of years a very unfortunate diminution in international grain prices as a result of the disastrous export subsidy wars which we have seen between the superpowers, the European Common Market and the United States. The world price for wheat has sunk to the point where it has been in the $2 range with predictable effects on our farming communities in Saskatchewan and across Canada.
This government has supported prairie agriculture through a series of initiatives from the 1985 drought, Special Grains I, Special Grains II, the western grain stabilization changes, crop insurance, the Canadian Crop Drought Assistance Program, the FSAM I and II programs and, of course, the establishment of the long-term measures, NISA and GRIP, which were designed by the agricultural community to address the need for more certainty, more stability and the need for producers to know what their bottom line would be from year to year. Those programs are in their phase-in stage and I believe in the long term they will provide a level of stability that is very much needed in that sector.
The tragedy is that we had to have recourse to various ad hoc programs over the past number of years. The farm community does not like these programs. They do not like the programs, government does not like the programs and certainly the taxpayer of the country does not like the programs.
The problem is that when we come up against the United States and the European Community in providing support for farmers, it is very difficult because we are caught on this double-edged sword. One side of the sword is our dependence on export markets; 84 per cent
Supply
of our wheat is destined for export. The other side of the sword is our limited population. We have 27 million people in this country compared to some 330 million in Europe, 250 million in the United States. Farmers are tremendously dependent on exports and, at the same time, we have a very much smaller population able to find the money with which to subsidize the programs.
The programs that we have put in place cost the Canadian taxpayers, in their opinion, too much, and at the same time, do not support to the producers in the way in which, I am sure, all members in this House would like to see.
What is the root cause of it? It is pretty obvious. It is the intervention of other governments in other countries into agriculture. If we could get these major powers out of agriculture, out of this business of harmful subsidies, then I believe that our producers can compete with the best of them. There is no question that our Canadian producers can grow grain at lower cost and more efficiently than virtually any other area in the world with the possible exception of certain parts of the United States.
The objective clearly has to be to try to work internationally in any way we can to try to bring down these harmful subsidies. What I see in the Dunkel draft proposals is a considerable amount of hope. This may well be the light at the end of the tunnel for an area of our country which has been hard hit over a number of years.
The Uruguay round has been going on for better than five years. Some 108 countries have been at the table. All of them want the same thing, Every single country at that GATT table wants to have things wide open where they are strong and competitive and they want to close it up tight where they are weak or perceive that they are vulnerable to competition.
Canada is no different; 107 other countries feel the same way. What that tells me, Mr. Speaker, and I think it must be obvious to everyone is in that process of bargaining, you are going to get some of the things you want but you are not going to get everything you want. You reach some form of compromise. There is no way that Canada is going to achieve every facet, every possible objective that it has had on the table over the past five years.

February 12, 1992
Supply
In brief, the Dunkel proposals call for reductions of something like 36 per cent on expenditure outlays and 24 per cent of the volume of export subsidies. These cuts applied to the average annual amount on the base period from 1986 to 1990, put in plain terms, means a reduction of the European Community support by something in the order of 40 per cent. In terms of the dollar amount of the U.S. export subsidies, it is perhaps 50 per cent.
That can be nothing but good news for a grain and oil seeds sector that has been very hard hit. I do not believe that it would be in the interests of this country, or indeed of members of this House, to insist that Canada achieve every possible element of perfection in a possible GATT agreement.
The fact is that this draft text-I assume it is getting near the final stages because after all, these countries have been at the table for five years-if it is accepted by all of these 108 nations I think will be good over all for Canada.
Canada cannot unilaterally walk away from a process like this and leave 107 countries at the table. It cannot say: "Fine, you go ahead. We are going to drop out. We are going to leave the civilized world. We are going to function as a pariah group on our own. We are going to be at the mercies of the winds".
I think that would be a completely and utterly irresponsible approach. I have faith in our negotiators and I have faith that in the process the best interests of Canada are being pursued. Recognizing that we cannot possibly achieve every single element that we would like, all of the participants in this process are going to have take some water in their wine. All are going to come away with something less than they wish. That is the nature of negotiations, the give and take. On balance and looking at these proposals, I believe that over all, they are beneficial for Canadian agriculture and for Canada.
Hopefully it will be possible to strengthen them. Hopefully it will be possible to make the proposals better. However, I say that we cannot unilaterally walk away from an agreement that I believe over all is positive for Canadian agriculture.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I found myself agreeing more than disagreeing with the hon. member who just spoke until he got to the end and said that over all he felt that this agreement in its present form would be good for Canada.
My assessment, and that of many other people, is that this agreement in its present form would do for the structure of Canadian agriculture what the free trade agreement has done for the structure of manufacturing in Ontario. It is something we should all be alarmed about and something that we need to fight vigorously to resist.
There are two questions which I would like to address to the hon. member. In his remarks he mentioned the WGTA and the Crow benefit. I took from his remarks- and I hope I interpreted them correctly-that the amendment which the government made to our motion removing the words "in its present form" means that we can make the technical changes to WGTA which might be required under a GATT agreement and does not mean that this government is going to try to piggy back in changes to the method of payment under the guise of the GATT agreement. I think our negotiators have said very clearly that that is not the case.
Second, I would like to ask the member a question with respect to the Prime Minister's involvement in this issue. We have heard discussion today about the Prime Minister meeting with farm groups on February 18.
I assumed that the meeting that people were talking about was the Prime Minister accepting the long-standing invitation of the supply management groups to meet with them to address their concerns.
However, I have just found out that the Prime Minister has called a meeting of his own to which he has invited farm leaders from all sectors, including the grains and oil seeds sector and the suspicion is-the member might tell me that this is unfounded-that this might well be an attempt to divide and conquer the farm community. The concerns of the supply management people will be diluted in those discussions by the input and the presence of people who do not have the same concerns with this particular GATT agreement.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in answer to the first point regarding the WGTA benefit, I must tell the hon. member that I had the opportunity during the break in January to attend eight of the transportation hearings that were in my riding and benefited very much from them. I was able to hear the points of view of producers across an area of some 25,000 square miles and from what I heard from producers in my area was that the majority of them would favour retaining the Crow benefit in its present form, that is that it continue to be paid to the railways. Indeed, I have conveyed what I have heard to my colleagues down here.
February 12, 1992

At a couple of those meetings I also was put in a position of having to intervene and was able to point out that the GATT proposals may have some impact on the method of payment in the sense that there might be some reduction in the global amount but that nowhere in those proposals did it call for a change in the method of payment.
As the hon. member knows, there are at the present time across the country some 137 of these workshop style meetings that were initiated by the federal and provincial governments. I might say in passing I think it is unfortunate that the provincial government in Saskatchewan chose to back out of this process because I am not sure it was the responsible position to take. In any event these hearings are ongoing. The input received from producers will be gathered, summarized and presented to the various ministers across the country. No doubt further meetings will be convened among the 11 agriculture ministers and some decisions may or may not be taken. That, after all, was the whole purpose of this hearing process and this entire exercise.
The hon. member also raised the matter of the Prime Minister's involvement in regard to the GATT accord and these various agricultural issues. It is the hon. member's party which posed this motion which speaks to about five items. It talks about GATT. It talks about the maintenance of a viable and effective supply management. It talks about article XI. It talks about the Crow. It talks about export subsidies and environmental impact assessments and so on.
He talks about dividing and conquering, but the fact is that I think this motion is intact. There are five aspects to it, and I think it would be appropriate for the Prime Minister to meet with farm leaders across the country so that he can talk with them about the five items which the hon. member's own party has put on the floor.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was involved in the supply marketing system in the dairy industry for most of my life. I remember what it was like before supply management and where it put us. It is important to note that supply management controls supply and orderly marketing.
In this case it means that farmers produce food for a fair price and are not in financial trouble. It is important to note that today the Canadian chicken agency indicated
Supply
that within three years 86 per cent of Canadian producers would likely be out of business. Of 2,411, only 330 would remain.
Within two years they expect that the poultry industry will have ceased in Atlantic Canada.
I urge the government to support article XI and supply management. It is the backbone of the mixed farming industry in Prince Edward Island and Atlantic Canada, and it is a system that takes care of itself. It supplies food. If we look at the United States and the great difficulty the farmers are having there, if we look at the great difficulty in the Soviet Union where they do not have enough food, I think it is very important. We have the best system in the world today.
I urge the government to press forward and support article XI and supply management.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think we seriously have to ask whether the government is credible in this debate today and whether the government is levelling with us. The evidence would indicate no to both questions.
I say that because the agriculture minister this afternoon certainly put his remarks in the past tense, indicating that he feels that the Dunkel report is a finished job and will become part of a new GATT agreement. In other words, the government has caved in. It has thrown the towel in.
The member for Swift Current-Maple Creek-Assi-niboia, who just finished speaking moments ago, certainly sounded as if he had thrown in the towel. He pretty well said: "That is all we are going to get, we had better take it".
There is another piece of evidence to indicate that the government has caved in. At the agriculture committee meeting yesterday and again today when department officials or members of this government spoke, they were very happy to talk about the consequences of a new GATT agreement, that is if it has to do with the WGTA, the farm safety net programs, or consequences dealing with subsidies or prices. They will talk your head off about those possible consequences resulting from a new GATT deal including the Dunkel report.

February 12, 1992
Supply
However, if you ask them about the impact on supply management, they suddenly become mute. They do not say anything. They do not give us any information. Has one member of the government stood up today and described the possible consequences to supply management if the Dunkel report is accepted? Not on your life. They will not say anything.
We asked the government for any results of impact studies. We asked last week. It started off saying that there was not even an impact study requested. Of course we know that is not true.
Why will it not give us this information? It is because it knows dam well that it would be embarrassed with the results if they were made public. What would be the impact on self-sufficiency of food in this country? That is a very responsible request. Should we not have that information? Food is very important to us. A country should be able to feed itself. Yet when we ask the government if it has done a study with respect to self-sufficiency in food, the answer is that apparently it has not. To me, that is sheer irresponsibility. Has there been an impact study on the environment? No.
I do not think there has been any kind of impact study, or at least it is withholding the results with respect to the so-called numbers. We get the numbers from the supply management people but we get nothing from this government.
If we lose supply management, let us face it, it is the end of orderly marketing for that sector of agriculture. It is the end of orderly marketing. It is the end of stability in that sector of agriculture. There is no doubt about it.
What we will have, and let us put it in straight words, will be dog eat dog, the law of the jungle. It will be a wild, unfettered open market system. That is what we will get.
We have had one of the most responsible, stable, productive sectors of the agricultural economy and we are going to do what? Give it away. That is what it looks like. We will lose the family farm. It will be replaced by huge, greedy, gluttonous corporate farms. We will be closer to the American style. We will be closer to the
United States model, which is dominated by chaos and a lot of impoverished farmers. Is that the kind of system we want? It certainly looks like it to me when you listen to the government members speaking.
What we have in the way of supply management in this countiy is the envy of the world. In 20 years the system has grown tremendously. It has been tremendously successful. It has given consumers a strong supply of food at veiy good prices, the second best in the world. In the last 20 years the market has grown 50 per cent. To me, that is a mark of success. Are we going to blow it?
Australia did away with supply management. I have a piece of news for those consumers who might think that if we could just do away with supply management we would get lower prices. Look at the Australian experience. It has not had lower prices.
What is at stake is a $10 billion industry, and possibly as many as 100,000 jobs are at stake. Let us not forget the value of quotas or the value of the investment. It has been estimated that if we lose supply management, if the Dunkel report goes through as is, quotas now worth billions will be lost overnight.
The reason we proposed our subamendment is simple. We want the Prime Minister involved in these negotiations.
The Prime Minister should be embarrassed. He goes around telling the world he is a good friend of George Bush. In fact he even goes boating with him at Kenne-bunkport. He is a member of the G-7. He got George Bush to help him try to get the United Nations job. Why is he not calling in a few IOUs. Why is he not getting George Bush onside? The man should be embarrassed. That is why we are proposing this subamendment, to get the Prime Minister involved, to make him put his money where his mouth is. He stands up and says: "We are for clarifying and strengthening article XI". If that is the case, get to Bush and get to the President of the European Community.
I have just one more remark, Mr. Speaker.
February 12, 1992

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take part in this debate tonight. As we are entering the final weeks of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, otherwise known as the GATT, the question the Canadian public should be asking after this debate is whether the Prime Minister, the two agriculture ministers, our Canadian negotiators and this government, are doing, have done, and will do everything possible to retain article XI.
Obviously article XI must remain in the GATT. Certainly the farmers who are here this week and who will be here next week do not believe that the government has done everything it can possibly do. We do not believe it.
Our amendment tonight is that the Prime Minister see President Bush, see our allies in Europe and say how important article XI is to this country, to our farmers, to our communities which are dependent. Article XI, for those at home who are just tuning in, relates in the GATT to our ability as a country to secure a constant supply of domestically produced milk, eggs, chicken, and turkey with stable prices.
It is an uncertain time for Canadian industry. The farmers in the east, in the Atlantic, have the most to lose if article XI is not in the GATT. We are so far away from the big markets and we are so close to the United States we could be overrun by those products.
It has been said here in Canada the production alone of these farms goods; milk, dairy, eggs, and poultry is a $10.2 billion dollar industry.
In Atlantic Canada the dairy, egg and poultry industries in 1991 employed 6,250 people. The returns for that in 1990 in those same industries, dairy, egg and poultry, was $642.4 million. This accounts for 36 per cent of all Atlantic cash receipts.
Over 50 per cent of Nova Scotia agriculture is based on products of supply managed goods. In my own riding of South West Nova-and the most recent statistics are still only 1986, these are not today's-but if you go by 1986, the last census taken, there were 79 supply managed farms.
This is only 13 per cent of the farms in my riding but they accounted for 30 per cent of the total farm sales in South West Nova. Those farm sales were $30,794,837 and every dollar counts in South West Nova as it does in all of Nova Scotia when you think of how many jobs have been lost in the area.
We are not talking beef. We are not talking pork. We are not talking mink, fox or fruit. We are talking dairy, egg and poultry in a very small area of Canada.
Supply management has given Canada a prosperous, productive agricultural sector. We have developed sup-

February 12, 1992
Supply
ply management with our domestic needs in mind only, not to go after other markets.
The fact that article XI is on the table at all is because of the absurd subsidy war between the United States and Europe. It has been estimated that if the Dunkel agreement goes ahead and quotas are eliminated, our supply managed farmers will face a massive drop in the value of their assets. I do not want to go into that because my time is limited, but this does not consider the immediate impact of quota on farm financing.
Bankers have often used 50 per cent of quota value as collateral for loans. Taking this indirect value into account, it has been estimated that under tariffication, which is what we will have in this industry if this government does not get to work fast, dairy farmers could face a drop of between 35 per cent and 40 per cent in the value of their farm assets.
According to the report that was given to us by the backgrounder here today, the industry will be particularly hard hit from the start in the maritimes and in the west. Producers and processors will be forced out of business. I take that as a direct quote on the east. It will affect all of Canada. We will not be able to compete if there is no article XI for our own domestic needs to be supplied here in Canada.
I said earlier that the question Canadians have to ask and have to ask every politician in this House is: Is this government, is our Prime Minister, actually doing enough for Canadians? I say that in light of the motion that is before us tonight, and I would like to re-read it.
We would like to see, and our motion amended the main motion before this House: "that this House call upon the Prime Minister to involve himself personally in the GATT negotiations in the interests of Canada's dairy, egg and poultry producers by meeting with the President of the United States and with the President of the European Community in order to secure their support and to do so in co-operation with other countries that agree with Canada's position on a strengthened and clarified GATT article XT'.
Now I only want to say two things in the two minutes that are left to me. We cannot afford as a country not to put all our effort into maintaining article XI, because we do not have the same conditions that they do in the United States. Our climate is different; we have fewer
people; and we have transportation costs that are very high for most Canadians, if they have to pay the actual cost.
We came up with a beautiful plan called supply management. I do not understand why our Canadian supply management has to be questioned under the GATT. I do not understand why our ministers of agriculture, the two of them, and our Prime Minister and our negotiators cannot from this day on be talking to our allies in Europe and in Canada. We are not hurting them with our supply management. It is a subsidy war perhaps that is going on between the United States and Europe in their agricultural forum. Why take it out on Canada's supply management?
You know we have allies that we should be going after. We do not see the Prime Minister meeting with Japan; we do not see him going after other allies that are with us on this problem. We don't see him doing anything.
That is why, as I said before, the farmers are here today. That is why they are meeting next week. Unless we impress on the Prime Minister and his ministers of agriculture to go out and start negotiating to keep article XI, I am afraid our agricultural industry will be very much depleted.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to have the opportunity today to be part of this debate. I must say, however, that this situation is of great concern for the constituents of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell. In my riding, according to Agriculture Canada, there are 109 milk producers, as well as many poultiy and egg producers. The supply managed industry generates some $10 billion in revenues in Canada. Some 100,000 jobs are at stake here today and some 40,000 family farms are in danger. Why? Because our government is failing. That's why. Since 1987, Canada has been taking part in talks to amend the multilateral GATT agreement, the famous Uruguay round. What are some of its purposes? Well,
Supply
Mr. Speaker, first, the nations want to include agriculture in the GATT provisions and in doing so, put an end to the export subsidy war going on between some countries. I think everybody wants to see that subsidy war come to an end. But that is not the point. What will be the cost of putting an end to that war? We must sacrifice some innocent people because, evidently, in the egg, milk and poultry industry, exportation is not an item. There is practically none. So they did not cause the export war, at least not the producers of the commodities that I just mentioned. And even so, Canada is not to blame in this export war, which is mainly between the United States of America and the European Common Market. In any case, the producers I just listed are not part of it and of course have nothing to gain and eveiything to lose.
In December, Art Dunkel, the president of the GATT negotiations, tabled a document which included all the articles on which the parties agreed; in cases where there was no agreement, he chose a middle position himself or a position of his own and put it in his report, which he then circulated. What does that document include? It includes a tariff system to replace article XI of GATT which allows us today to have quantitative restrictions at the border. Of course, those tariffs will be lowered by about 6 per cent a year or 36 per cent over six years. The tariffs will eventually be eliminated, in some cases in the short term, in others it will take longer. Of course, nothing will prevent U.S. imports from flooding the Canadian market and undermining the whole credibility of the supply management system we have in Canada.
The hon. member for Algoma put it well just now. He asked the Prime Minister to get involved personally in these negotiations; he demanded that he telephone or contact the President of the United States, the President of the European Common Market and the other parties so that Canadian producers of milk, poultry and eggs, who have nothing to do with that subsidy war, will not be the victims. What the hon. member for Algoma asks is quite reasonable. It is now up to the Prime Minister. It was up to him from the beginning, but it is not enough to telephone George Bush in Washington. The Prime Minister himself should have gone there and elsewhere to ensure that 100,000 jobs and 40,000 family farms in Canada were not jeopardized. Now we are at the eleventh hour of the last day and what should have been done has not been done. Of course, since it has not been

done, or at least not done well enough, our producers are now threatened.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 - GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to join in this debate today because for the farming community I represent this is a veiy important debate.
We want the people in the Fraser Valley to know that this government and members on both sides of this House are in support of what Canada is trying to do in the GATT negotiations.
To begin with, I would like to restate the government's position in the GATT talks. Canada went into the Uruguay round of negotiations in 1986 with four principal objectives.
First of all, we were seeking substantial reductions in trade distorting subsidies, particularly export subsidies. Second, we wanted improved, predictable and more secure access to export markets through a reduction in tariffs and non-tariff barriers.
February 12, 1992

Third, we wanted clearer and fairer GATT rules that apply equally to all countries, including a strengthened and clarified article XI-I will have more to say about this point later-the elimination of countries' specific exemptions and better disciplines on the use of countervailing duties. [DOT]
Fourth, we wanted to see the development of a framework of rules to prevent the abuse of health and sanitary regulations as disguised barriers to trade.
It bears repeating that this position was drafted with the full co-operation of all parts of the agrifood industry. In our recent discussions with industry representatives they have asked us to hold firm to this stand, and we have agreed.
I, along with a number of our colleagues this morning, met with the leadership of the marketing agencies. In the clearest terms possible, this was Canada's position in 1986 and it is Canada's position now. It will be our position when the negotiations conclude.
The negotiators have been back at work in Geneva for almost a month now, working with the draft text prepared by Arthur Dunkel, the GATT Secretary-General and chairman of the agriculture negotiating group.
Canada has joined with the other 107 GATT members in accepting this draft as the basis for negotiations because we believe it holds considerable promise for establishing a freer, more stable and less distorted agricultural trading community.
Reductions in trade distorting domestic support and substantial cuts in subsidized exports would create a more level international playing field.
This would help to bring the agricultural trade war under effective control and allow Canadian farmers to compete on fairer terms. It would also have a more positive effect on grain and other agricultural commodity prices in the long term.
We would still be free to support our farmers through programs that are best intended for Canadian agriculture. There are no limits on how much government support can be provided if it meets the "green" criteria. "Green" support measures will be free from countervail.
That is a thumbnail sketch of what is proposed in the Dunkel text as a basis for further negotiations. However,
Supply
we are disappointed that the draft text does not call for the strengthening and clarification of article XI, the section of the GATT agreement which allows us to impose border controls on supply managed products.
Instead, Mr. Dunkel would have us replace our current import quotas with tariffs and we would be unable to impose any import quotas during the implementation period. Mr. Dunkel has told us that he believes comprehensive tariffication without exception is the only possible way to reconcile the United States and the European Community.
In his view it is the possible way to secure an agreement. I want to re-emphasize that Canada does not agree with Mr. Dunkel's assessment of the situation.
While we are treating the Dunkel paper as a basis for negotiations, we have remained as committed as ever to a clarified article XI. Our ambassador made this point very clearly on January 13 when the talks resumed.
Our experience with supply management tells us that it is an effective marketing system that does not distort trade. We continue to believe that the best way to protect supply management is through a strengthened and clarified article XI. I should point out that article XI, as it stands, is not an acceptable alternative.
Recent GATT panel rulings have raised a number of uncertainties as to which processed products are eligible to receive import protection under article XI. In the past several months, the Canadian government has worked tirelessly to promote our position with Mr. Dunkel and the other GATT members. The Minister of Agriculture, the Minister for International Trade, the Minister of State for Grains and Oilseeds, and the Minister of State for Agriculture have met their counterparts from the United States, the European Community, Japan, Korea and other GATT members.
In replying to a question from the opposition last week asking whether he had been part of the GATT talks with other heads of state, the Prime Minister said as reported in Hansard for February 5:
I have met with everybody from Art Dunkel to President Bush, to President Mitterrand and to the president of the European commission. We had a meeting with Jacques Delors that lasted in excess of three hours precisely on this point. We made the case, chapter and verse, about its importance not only to the nation but to each individual producer. We are going to make it again.

February 12, 1992
Supply
At every opportunity we have pushed for support for the Canadian position, specifically the strengthening and clarifying of article XI of the GATT. Between now and March 1, when all participants are to table revised offers on agriculture, the negotiations are moving ahead on four tracks.
The trade negotiations committee is discussing possible changes to the package. The major delegations will have to agree here to any significant amendments. Inconsistencies and omissions in the draft text are being addressed by a legal drafting group without changing the balance of rights and obligations. Schedules of initial commitments on services are being developed in market access negotiations. Market access negotiations on goods are developing schedules of market access concessions as well as commitments on export subsidies and internal support for agriculture.
When the country schedules are tabled on March 1, intensive negotiations among trading partners will likely begin again. All parties agree that the round should be wrapped up by Easter. That will leave us just over eight months to prepare for implementation, which is to begin on January 1, 1993.
Speaking as the member from the Fraser Valley in British Columbia, when I go to farm meetings I am surprised at the age bracket of the people who attend these meetings. There are many young farmers getting into agriculture in Canada. I know they are concerned about what is happening at the GATT talks as we are concerned here in this House tonight. I want to assure them that we are doing everything in our power to make sure that we have a successful conclusion to this round of negotiations.
This is the first time that agriculture has been part of the GATT negotiations on all levels of the GATT, which started back in 1986. Our negotiating stance has not wavered since 1986 and it is consistent to this day. We ask for the support of the agriculture community and members from both sides of this House so that Canada's position is maintained on a consistent basis as we all want to ensure that we keep the supply management system we have in agriculture in our country.
The Government of Canada is committed to supply management and we are committed to the strengthening and clarifying of article XI.
