Mr. Speaker, during the member's remarks I noticed he said that one of the advantages of the current Dunkel proposal would be better prices in the long run for grain farmers.
He should be aware of the half a dozen or so projected results that I have been able to see, none of which originated in Canada by the way. The GATT is not going to increase incomes to farmers. We will have to rely on El Nino or some dramatic weather change to do that. This political change is not going to mean better incomes for farmers. In fact, it will have the opposite result.

That, in the opinion of this House, a full review of the media's portrayal of violence toward and abuse of women and children, should be held by an appropriate committee of the House of Commons with the aim of making recommendations as to how better to protect innocent Canadians from being exposed to such portrayals without interfering unduly with artistic freedom and freedom of the press.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I indeed feel very fortunate to have the opportunity to speak to the House today on my private member's motion No. 534, introduced on May 23,
1991.	The motion reads:
That, in the opinion of this House, a full review should be held by an appropriate committee of the House of Commons of the media's portrayal of violence toward women and children.
February 12, 1992

This review would make recommendations as to how we might protect innocent Canadians from being exposed to such portrayals without interfering unduly with artistic freedom and freedom of the press.
My comments will speak to the issue surrounding violence and abuse against women, violence against children, violence on aboriginal reserves, violence in rural communities as well as the media's coverage and the media's portrayal of these issues at the national and local level.
I wish to preface my remarks by indicating that the statistics I bring forward are not presented for sensational effect or drama. They are stated to bring to the attention and awareness of Canadians the magnitude of the problem of violence in our society.
My statistics have been gleaned from various sources, including Health and Welfare Canada, the Canadian Association of Sexual Assault Centres, transition house directors, aboriginal groups, Canadian publications, including the newsletter of the Federation of Women Teachers Associations of Ontario, as well as recent American and Canadian studies.
Canadian research indicates that the incidence of violence against women and children has escalated. In Canada in 1989, 119 women were murdered in domestic relationships. Most publications say that one in ten Canadian women is battered by her male partner. The Smith study from Toronto in 1987 suggests the number is closer to one in four women who is physically abused by her male partner.
The insidious part of all of this is that 80 per cent of the children in those homes witnessed their father's violence, thus leaving indelible scars on their developing personalities.
The Canadian Association of Sexual Assault Centres tells us that every 17 minutes a Canadian woman is raped. An alarming 84 per cent of assaulted women are raped by someone they know. Date rape is the newest form of violence for women to fear. The attitudes of young people toward date rape are disturbing.
Results of recent studies at Toronto high schools and York University found that 54 per cent of high school boys and 42 per cent of girls sampled said it was acceptable for a boy to hold a girl down and force her to have sexual relations with him if he had spent a lot of money on her, they had dated a long time, or she had led him on.
Private Members' Business
In another study, 65 per cent of the young men and 47 per cent of the young women thought a man could force a woman to have sex if they had been dating for more than six months.
Mr. Speaker, children are victims too. The true extent of physical and sexual abuse is difficult to determine because it is usually the most extreme cases which come to the attention of the authorities.
The Canadian Medical Association estimates that
8,000	children are badly injured by abuse every year. The Badgley report in 1984 claims that one of three males and two of three females have been victims of unwanted sexual acts before they reach the age of 21.
Statistics do not describe the scars that abusers leave on their victims. Men who battered consistently report that they had witnessed their mothers being battered and received physical abuse themselves. Violence was learned as a source of power and control in their first social group, the family.
The predicament of children who are captive in violent homes is terrible. In their study, "Children of Battered Women", Joffe, Wolfe and Wilson quote the work of L. Walker, and I quote as well:
Children who live in a battering relationship experience the most insidious form of child abuse.
Whether or not they are physically abused by either parent is less important than the pyschological scars they bear from watching their father beat their mother.
They learn to become part of the dishonest conspiracy of silence.
They learn to lie, to prevent inappropriate behaviour and they learn to suspend the fulfilment of their needs rather than risk another confrontation. They expend a lot of energy avoiding problems.
So continues that study.
Not every child exposed to wife battering becomes violent. But it is probably safe to say that children who witness violence will experience psychological consequences. Wife battering is a problem with so many implications that it can be believed as the invisible core of violence in our society.
Family violence and abuse affects everyone including all social, racial, cultural, religious, economic and professional classes. However, aboriginal family violence and abuse is becoming a major concern in Canada. Studies indicate that family violence is escalating dramatically in aboriginal communities. Often aboriginal people do not view the problem as one of offender-victim relationship so much as one of community dysfunction of which family violence is but one symptom.

February 12, 1992
Private Members' Business
Consequently, solutions should be viewed in terms of holistic community-wide healing processes which must be planned, developed and implemented by and with aboriginal people. At present, many social service personnel on reserves find they have neither the training nor the resources to deal with the dramatic increase in the number of disclosures of physical or sexual abuse. Indian communities must seek to empower themselves to resolve their problems. To achieve this end, they require long-term commitment from governments and their own leadership.
Violence against women and children is not limited to big cities across Canada. It is also a reality in rural Canada. Patterns are changing in rural Canada. Rural abuse has taken on a new dimension at a time where the economy of rural areas is bleak. All of the horrors of city family violence are right there along the gravel roads of rural Canada. Small communities are under stress, families are in conflict, alcohol and drug abuse are significant factors. All of these difficulties may well be the setting and may well be setting the stage in rural communities for ongoing abuse in families where there has been little prior history.
How does the media factor in all of the above, Mr. Speaker? The statistics would suggest the media contributes to and supports the culture of violence that the child sees in the home. Studies by Molnar indicate that in 1982, 3 to 11 year olds were exposed to 15 hours a week of violent cartoons. Carlsson-Paige and Levine found that by 1987 it had escalated to 43 hours a week. That was likely before the Ninja Turtles too I would suggest.
The average child could spend the equivalent of 22 school days a year watching violence on television. There is the potential for television to teach children a view which includes violence as an acceptable solution to resolving conflict. Friedrich-Cofer and Huston in 1986 concluded that television violence definitely affects aggression.
It should not be too surprising then that dating violence has become a problem in Canada. Young people from 12 to 17 years of age are the primary consumers of pornography in Canada. Check and Lacrosse in conducting surveys of attitudes toward pornography in metro Toronto high school students reported that 35 per cent of
those sampled reported watching scenes of rape, torture and bondage.
It would seem imperative therefore that those engaged in media programming as well as all forms of media reporting be made cognizant of the significance of their industry as to how it impacts as a role model upon our children and youth.
Solutions to the problem of violence and abuse must come from all sectors of society, including government at all levels.
The members in this House are aware of the initiatives which have been undertaken by the government over the last number of years to deal with the questions of violence against women and children in our communities. Many organizations outside government should be lauded for having joined forces with us to implement such initiatives as the Child Sexual Abuse Guidelines for community workers. I am proud to say that this protocol was developed by working professionals across Canada and it was indeed shared by a constituent, Laura Car-ment, who is the regional director of Child and Youth Services, Mental Health Services, Saskatchewan Mental Health in Regina.
The recently announced $136 million federal initiative on family violence will give all jurisdictions in Canada the opportunity over the next four years to develop programs to address the specific needs in their communities. There is, of course, support for the Canadian panel for violence against women established by the minister responsible for the status of women, to investigate the extent of violence in our society and to determine workable solutions.
There are those in Canada who would suggest the minister should ultimately call for a royal commission on violence against women.
These are laudable programs and initiatives, but we can and we must do more to address the problems of violence against women and children in Canada.
As the federal government, we should seek to form new partnerships with other levels of government, nongovernment organizations, professional associations, community groups and the private sector, to identify, treat and prevent problems of violence and abuse.
February 12, 1992

It is with this thought in mind that I put forward the view that the media has a pivotal role to play in facing the problems in being part of the solution in dealing with violence against women and children.
Since the media is one of the primary distributors of the message, I believe it is essential that the media should be enlisted to work in concert with our national goals and framework to deal with the problems of violence against women and children in our capacity to prevent family violence.
There are many questions which must be asked, and these are just but a few. Does the media have a code of ethics or protocol regarding the programming and reporting of scenes of violence and abuse against women and children. Would advertisers consider boycotting programs that display such violence? Would viewers consider boycotting both programs and advertisers who display and/or condone violence and abuse against women and children? These and other related questions constitute a major concern to me and I urge this House to give this matter serious consideration.
I would also at this time like to thank my wife, Shirley, for the role she played in the development of my interest and concern in this subject. Together we have a vision of Canada as a country that takes true and compassionate care of its children, its seniors and those who are defenceless against brutality, a country in which the vulnerable among us can live in dignity and safety, free from violence. I hope everyone in this House will share this vision with us.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very happy to stand in this House tonight and support the motion by my hon. colleague and good friend, the member for Regina-Wascana. I certainly support very much the motion that he has brought forward.
Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of our burgeoning technological society today is the predeliction for violence in the media, and in particular in that most influential of the media, television. It just happened that last weekend Halifax was getting its third major storm in a week and I could not step outside my house. I was flipping around the television channels and on every commercial channel, as opposed to say Newsworld or some of the other news channels or the movie channels,
Private Members' Business
you had cartoons for children. In every one, every single one-and it was around nine o'clock on a Saturday morning-there was what I consider, and I would suggest what most people in this House would consider to be, an undue amount of violence.
My hon. friend mentioned the teenage mutant Ninja turtles-if I have the title correct-and those characters are extremely popular with very small children. Preschoolers in general are the ones who seem to be taken by that. On another channel there was some sort of a space cartoon where people were being decapitated, men and women both, by some sort of monster. One had a sort of eerie response to the fact that across this country children were sitting in front of those television sets, captivated by this, and getting a message that nobody really seriously could want to send to them.
We know that television is the most pervasive and popular of the media. As my hon. friend has said, we know that on average Canadian spend 23.4 hours per week in front of the television. Children spend a disproportionate amount of time in front of the television. In fact they spend more time in front of the television sets than they spend in school.
Mediawatch reported the most disturbing facts in its review of programming on R-rated television. Here are some of the figures. Women are more likely than men to be depicted nude and as going from fully clothed to either partially nude or nude. The body parts of females were far more likely to be shown in a disassembled manner than the body parts of males. That is tidying up the language. What a disassembled manner means is that women were more likely to be shown dismembered on television than men were.
Of the programs that contained a combination of sex and violence, 92 per cent had a female victim. Males were abused in only 8 per cent of cases. Women comprised 63 per cent of the instances of violence in English TV drama and 62 per cent in French TV drama. They composed an equally high percentage of those shown in what could be considered a somewhat subservient or a lot subservient manner. For example, if someone was being shown in a bathing-suit, underwear, skin-tight clothing or in a bathtub or shower scene, or grooming or unclothed, in all of these women were 60 per cent of the characterizations.

Private Members' Business
Even the media's portrayal of violence against women and children seems to go over the edge into the sensational. God knows we have enough actual incidents in our society of violence against women and children, but there is a tendency in the media today to take even these horrific situations and make them worse.
Rather that report on the daily incidents of violence against women and children, the reports tend to focus on usual aspects of this violence. For example, one only has to look at the coverage of the Polytechnique massacre and the explanations that were offered. One only has to look at the way some of the media reacted to this.
I know that my colleague from New Westminster- Burnaby, as well as the hon. minister, will remember in the report of the subcommittee on the status of women something I will never forget. It is the Maclean's magazine ad in the week after the Polytechnique massacre. It was brought to our attention in committee by a journalism professor from Carleton University. I will describe it, because certainly I read the issue of Maclean's that week and did not even notice it.
On the left-hand side is the study about the Polytechnique and there is a photograph of the flowers in the snow in front of the building that people left there that December day. On the right-hand side is an ad for the House of Birks, Canada's most famous and nation-wide jewellery and gift store. In the House of Birks ad is a head and shoulders of a woman and she is blue. In the medical term she is cyanotic. There is a chain hanging around her neck. It is quite artistic. It is quite sophisticated and, when we really look at it, it is quite frightening because in actual fact living women do not look like that; dead women look like that.
This was something that every one of us, I would wager, looked at that week and did not notice. As I said, I did not notice it. None of us noticed it until it was brought to our attention by this journalism professor. When we have something like that brought to our attention, we realize how even those of us who are attempting to fight this, for whom it has become an almost daily part of life to be arguing against these images and these symbols, can become toughened to the
whole scenario. How much worse is it for small children to be influenced by images of this?
I realize that my time is running short and I want to close by again reiterating my support for the hon. member's motion. I would also like to say that I particularly liked the closing portion of his motion which says: "Without interfering unduly with artistic freedom and freedom of the press".
Of course freedom of expression and artistic freedom are very important. However, I do not think that any of us-I know that the member would agree with me on this-would stand here and say that artistic freedom or freedom of the press would be impinged upon if we said that the time has come to stop the brutality and the degradation of women, children and people in general in the commonplace production of media events.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am also pleased to rise to support this motion put forward by the member for Regina-Wascana.
It is important for all members of this House to reinforce our commitment to eradicating violence against women and children. This is one step we can certainly take on the road to reaching that goal.
As the member who spoke before me said, the status of women subcommittee dealt with a number of issues around violence against women. This is one issue that was discussed at our committee hearings.
Some of the witnesses who appeared before the committee expressed concern about the powerful role of the media in socializing young people. They recommended that a component of the high school curriculum for young women and men should include the study of media representations of violence and the effect it has on all of our behaviours.
Judith Posner of the Association for Media Literacy informed the committee that violent imagery is portrayed by a variety of media, most of which is mainstream. Many of us think that it is not mainstream media that portrays this violence. However, most of it is mainstream: popular films, fashion advertisements, rock videos and pornography, which the member mentioned specifically in his motion.
February 12, 1992

The common themes or depictions in violent media images typically show an imbalance of power between men and women, as well as the presence of coercion. They intimate that women enjoy pain, violence and subjugation.
In certain popular slasher films, girls and women who are independent are more often the victims. They are usually the victims. Independent young women are shown to be brutally murdered in these films. The message is that you will pay a price for your autonomy and your independence.
It is important to talk about the incidents of violence in our society. Rarely does a day go by in this country in which Canadian media do not carry reports of sexual and physical assault perpetrated by trusted persons and strangers against girls and women.
The frequency with which incidents of this nature are reported in the media would leave most Canadians to conclude that violence against women is indeed a serious problem in Canada. In fact, the gravity of the situation is far greater than the number of cases in the news reports would suggest.
Research has shown that most women who are victims of violence do not report their victimization to the police. As a result, the actual incidence is largely invisible and absent from official crime statistics, and by extension from media coverage. Indeed, sexual assault and wife assault are two crimes known to be significantly under-reported relative to other crimes of violence.
A Canada-wide survey published in 1985 found that fewer than 40 per cent of female sexual assault victims and less than half of wife assault victims had made a report to the police.
Studies show us that women's reluctance to report violent attacks against them is related to a fear of retaliation that would result in further violence or death, a lack of confidence in the police, the courts, and feelings of guilt and embarrassment.
The national reporting system in Canada, the Uniform Crime Reporting System, contains statistics on criminal incidents in Canada. However, this data base includes only crimes reported to police, and records of reported incidents of wife assault are listed as general assaults.
The UCR does not contain descriptive information about the relationship between victims and offenders or about the circumstances of the offence which would
Private Members' Business
identify incidents of violence against women in the family.
It is very important that we talk about the numbers of people who are victims of violence in our society, the children and the women. The member for Regina-Was-cana has mentioned it but I will reiterate some of the statistics.
In 1989, 12,970 sexual assaults were known to the police. Between 1983 and 1989 the number of complaints of sexual assault made to the police increased by 93 per cent. Every 17 minutes there was a sexual assault committed in Canada and 90 per cent of the victims are female. One in four women will be sexually assaulted at some time in their lives, half of those assaults before a young woman reaches the age of 17. Between 63 per cent and 83 per cent of female victims will be sexually assaulted by someone they know, someone they trust.
There are between 14,000 and 18,000 sexual assaults in the province of Quebec alone every year.
We know that the incidence of assault against women, of violence against women, is higher for aboriginal women and disabled women. It is higher for any woman who is doubly disadvantaged in our society. The more vulnerable a woman is the more susceptible she is to violent attack.
Part of the motion presented by the member reads: "to protect innocent Canadians from being exposed to such portrayals". I would suggest that it is also important that we protect the women and children from the effect these portrayals have on the way we are treated by our society.
It has long been denied that there is any connection between violence in the mass media and actual acts of violence against women and children. However, it has been clearly shown that violence is on a continuum. Seemingly small incidents of sexism such as sexist jokes allow people to feel they have the right to put women down. This opens the door to greater acts of sexism and discrimination, right on up to physical violence and unfortunately sometimes to murder.
The portrayal in the media of women as objects, the portrayal in the media of women as subordinates of men, and the portrayal of women being violated have profound effects on our attitudes in society. They have profound effects not only on children but, as the member for Halifax said yesterday, we all become somewhat immune to the barrage of sexist advertising and the violence in the scheme of that advertising.

February 12, 1992
Private Members' Business
I am pleased to support the member's motion. I congratulate him for bringing it forward and I look forward to it being debated in committee.

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 8 p.m.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to speak to this motion that reads:
That, in the opinion of this House, a full review of the media's portrayal of violence towards and abuse of women and children, should be held by an appropriate committee of the House of Commons with the aim of making recommendations as to how better to protect innocent Canadians from being exposed to such portrayals without interfering unduly with artistic freedom and freedom of the press.
I also congratulate the preceding members who have spoken on the issue for the passion with which they support the motion.
The member who introduced this motion, the member for Regina-Wascana, has identified for us in a nutshell the magnitude of the problem of violence against women and children. This is truly an indictment of a serious ailment that exists in our society.
He has identified in an outline the causes and he has identified the media's portrayal of violence as a cause of violence against women and children. In so doing he has identified another group of causes of violence, those that are not media induced.
I should just say that this House has heard on several occasions the many non-media causes of violence, such as poverty. It is known that those who live in poor neighbourhoods, those who are poor are exposed to unusual behaviour which contributes to violence.
Recently I am told that there has been the depiction on one of our postage stamps of the picture of Satan. Now that to me, not in a religious sense, introduces the question of cult. It is known medically and psychologically that cult can contribute to violence. We know the tragic results of such a phenomenon.
We have to appreciate that children's games available to the public can damage the mental faculty of children and contribute to violent behaviour. It is known; it is a medical phenomenon.
As we look at the causes of violence, both the non-media and the media causes, another question has to be asked as to what is the interactive role of both, that
the sum of two influences can be more than just the additive sum, but in fact an interactive sum that accentuates the gravity of the problem.
So the question then naturally has to be asked: What types of portrayal by the media inflict adverse effects on children? To begin with, a committee that will study this problem naturally will review the literature available to it.
I am conscious of one study done at the Children's Hospital of Winnipeg, where I used to be. In fact, it concludes that violence portrayed on television does truly contribute to occurrence of violence among children.
Second, has there been any nation-wide study in Canada about the magnitude of this problem that we may not know? If such a study has not been done yet, certainly the federal government must be challenged to undertake such a study, to invite proposals for such a study from among our experts in the field so that we can undertake to define the actual magnitude as well as the available solutions that already exist.
A third question I would like to ask also is: What good value, if any, does violence portrayal serve? Is there any at all? That must be answered. Having said that I am conscious that, by and large, our media are very responsible, that they truly have at heart the welfare of our citizenry. Equally there are those who are motivated by greed, motivated by money and deliberately induce media violence. That, of course, must be looked at.
Violence is a major public health problem. Indeed, it is a major public health hazard that destroys not only the present, but the future generations as well.
So I welcome this motion and if, in fact, we would not take a vote on this motion, then I will make an undertaking to this House that I will bring this to the attention of the standing committee on health and welfare and to the subcommittee on health so that this issue, indeed, does not die after this motion has been debated in this Parliament because there is a bigger question. What can government do to solve the problem once identified, and meanwhile, what services do we provide so that those who have already been victims may now be attended to, healed and cured, so that we will only be attending to the future victims.
February 12, 1992

Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, I believe that we, as parliamentarians, must make a statement on this issue.
While negotiations or discussions have taken place with members of the other parties, I believe that unanimous consent may be obtained to adopt the following motion and because of the expressed interest in the media's role, the motion reads as follows:
That the Standing Committee on Communications and Culture do undertake a full review of the media's portrayal of violence towards and abuse of women and children with the aim of making recommendations as to how better to protect innocent Canadians from being exposed to such portrayals without interfering unduly with artistic freedom and freedom of the press.
This is moved by myself, seconded by the member for Westminister-Burnaby.
